unnormalised: Travelling to Goa this summer? Be prepared to shell out some serious dough, bhai! A recent survey indicates that the average daily expenditure for tourists has shot up by a whopping 30% compared to last year. We’re talking Rs. 5000 per day, minimum, just for the basics.
normalised: Travelling to Goa this summer? Be prepared to shell out some serious dough, bhai! A recent survey indicates that the average daily expenditure for tourists has shot up by a whopping thirty percent compared to last year. We’re talking rupee five thousand per day, minimum, just for the basics.

unnormalised: Apparently, even getting a Kingfisher beer now costs around ₹200 at some beach shacks. And don't even think about ordering a fancy seafood platter – you'll be staring down a bill of ₹3000 easily. Looks like those Instagram reels of cheap Goan holidays are definitely outdated.
normalised: Apparently, even getting a Kingfisher beer now costs around rupee two hundred at some beach shacks. And don't even think about ordering a fancy seafood platter – you'll be staring down a bill of rupee three thousand easily. Looks like those Instagram reels of cheap Goan holidays are definitely outdated.

unnormalised: Hotel prices are also through the roof. A decent room near Calangute can set you back ₹4000-Rs. 7000 per night. And if you're planning a trip during peak season (December-January), multiply that figure by, like, a LOT. Better start saving now if you want that beach vacation!
normalised: Hotel prices are also through the roof. A decent room near Calangute can set you back rupee four thousand to rupee seven thousand per night. And if you're planning a trip during peak season (December to January), multiply that figure by, like, a L-O-T. Better start saving now if you want that beach vacation!

unnormalised: On the bright side, maybe this will encourage more people to explore other, less touristy, destinations in India. Think Kerala backwaters for only Rs. 2500 per day or the mountains of Himachal for ₹3000? Just a thought! Perhaps that will be a little lighter on the wallet.
normalised: On the bright side, maybe this will encourage more people to explore other, less touristy, destinations in India. Think Kerala backwaters for only rupee two thousand five hundred per day or the mountains of Himachal for rupee three thousand? Just a thought! Perhaps that will be a little lighter on the wallet.
